displayed_text: Patient: Oh, yeah. Doctor: Okay. You know well when you’re on chemo she’s going to know, so. Patient: Yeah. Uh, I really hate the idea of losing my hair. Doctor: You’ll probably just get thinning. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because you have a lot of hair. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s folks who have like not so much hair at this age who just easily lose it. You have a lot of hair. Patient: Yes. When I was on the uh Cometriq. Doctor: Um hum. Patient: It started a little thinning but it was turning white. Doctor: Yeah. Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. It depends. Sometimes I’m on gel pills and sometimes I’m on pills, pills. Doctor: So, those are the three medicines you take? Patient: Yes. Doctor: So the Eliquis, the Wellbutrin, and your calcium with vitamin D in it? Patient: Right. Doctor: Nothin’ new? Nothing new for bowels? Anything for pain? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. (Pause10sec) Patient: No. Doctor: Heart failure? Patient: No. Doctor: Any issues with – did you ever have a blood transfusion?

Patient: Is it? Doctor: I may need to give you medicine to help control it. Like Imodium and things like that. Patient: Yeah, well then, okay. ‘Cuz, yeah, I’m taking the stool softener a day thinking that, that, that, you know? And then it be like watery. Doctor: Mmm, hmm. Patient: Yeah. It be like, it be like water. Doctor: Okay. Yeah, I think I’m going to give you medication. That way, when you’re out and about and all that, you can take that, and that won’t make you go so fast. Patient: Man. Man, that was so bad, so bad. Doctor: So, Patient: I did it twice on myself, man. ‘Cuz I went out, and I had to catch the bus back home. Man, it’s like I had to walk home ‘cuz I didn’t want to get on the bus. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: They’ll be saying, “What’s that smell like shit.” Doctor: Hmm.

Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: You know whether we’ve completely treated a couple of men and now we’re waiting to go up or whether or not we’re ready to go right now. So that would be a slot availability. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Your thoughts or questions about that? Patient: Well you’re going to coordinate with Dr. G. Doctor: I will coordinate with him the sort of the decision about have you progressed. Family Member: Mm,hmm. Doctor: And then I’ll print out these consent forms for you that you can take and sort of that he can look at as well. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And we can sort of decide which one makes more sense for you, or none of them may make any sense, and that really because your scans or worse, you’re having more symptoms. You know the textbook answer right now is go to chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm. Patient: And how soon would that start?

Family Member: Yeah, that’s what it is Healthcare Professional: Breaking bad news Doctor: Yes, yes, I thought he meant Breaking Bad like the TV Family Member: Yeah, that's what I’m thinking Healthcare Professional: No, No Doctor: I’m, like, did J___ do something I’m not aware of? (laughter) Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that.

Patient: No. No. No. From south to north. Doctor: North. Yeah. Patient: So but it wasn’t that warm in Florida these last few weeks. Doctor: So, we, we’re on camera right now. (waves to camera) Patient: I guess so. Doctor: I hope you brought your Grammy material with you. Patient: Yeah. Yeah. My publicist is very on call. Doctor: Yeah. So anything new going on? Patient: No. I mean as far as how I feel. Doctor: How do you feel? Patient: Yeah. Okay. Doctor: No new pains? No new issues urinating? Nothing else? Patient: No. I still wake up a couple of times a night you know and go but uh other than that I’m pretty active, play golf a couple of times a week. You know? Nothing slows me down.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because I need to check, if that, that we were to move you to, let’s say your AR-V7 was positive - Patient: Right. Doctor: They may want you to stay on the Enzalutamide. Patient: Right, right. Doctor: Or we could stop the TGF-A drug. Patient: Right. Doctor: And, then, you could move into that study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If you are AR-V7 negative and, uh, phase one study is of more interest to you, we can say, “Okay, you’re gonna stop as of this date the, the current study.” Patient: Right-- the drugs Doctor: And then we could reserve the slot for the new trial.

Family Member: I was always taught it’s an overgrowth of whatever. Doctor: Yeah. The cancer cells- Family Member: The cells just keep reproducing, reproducing, reproducing. Doctor: That’s it. It doesn’t know when to stop growing, which is the problem. Family Member: Right. Doctor: So it’s, you know, affected your bones. It’s affected some of the lymph nodes. So is it going like crazy gangbusters? No. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: I ain’t seen it in my lymph nodes. I check my lymph nodes. I ain’t seen none in my lymph nodes. Doctor: Well, you can’t see it. It’s inside when I do scans. So the good part is you don’t hurt or feel bad. Thank goodness. Family Member: Right. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So that’s great. But it doesn’t mean that we don’t do stuff because that’s why I check scans because it’s inside. So that’s, that’s why. Family Member: Um. Okay.

Family Member: He has tears in his eyes because he wants to be the man. And God is the man. He puts whoever in the position has to do whatever they have to do. Doctor: Yeah Family Member: But the fact is we’re able to do it. It doesn’t matter which pocket it comes. Patient: Well I wasn’t out there. So I’m glad I wasn’t out there. DOC Doctor: Well that was not appropriate. Family Member: And the point is in situations like that you can’t join a group, you can’t join a crowd, you have to stand out in a separate entity and say well I’m not gonna stoop to their level but I’m not gonna be stupid either. Doctor: Yeah so if are issues along the way – Family Member: They gave me this application to fill out. Doctor: - let me know and we can work from this. Okay. But this was inappropriate anyway the way they confronted you like that. Family Member: Yeah, because it was harsh. Had we been a little bit older or fearful or… Doctor: Yeah, I know. Family Member: - not able to speak to ourselves we would have given - Doctor: Right, no, I agree with you.
FAM Sometimes people come in here and fall for that and they’re gonna give them part of their rent money and that’s what they to live. You never know. No, I agree.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We’re just you know, we’re having our usual conversation that we have. What’s new? What’s the deal with going to Alabama and going straight, no breaks? Patient: I took breaks, but I just didn’t take enough. Doctor: Is your leg swollen? Can I take a look? Patient: Yeah. Might have to pull this down. Doctor: Why don’t you come on up here and see what’s going on. Patient: It’s up in here where it’s been. Doctor: Really? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Well, we can’t, you know. That part’s okay. Let me see this other skinny leg. Patient: Yeah, you’re right they’re skinny. Doctor: There’s no change there so that’s good but you think up here is swollen? Patient: Well, no, I don’t think it’s swollen. It’s just like a…

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Where it would have been an issue is if you’d gotten so much that you didn’t have any bone marrow reserve left, you know, like you’re perpetually having a low red blood cell count and need a blood transfusion but that’s not you so it’s something we consider but definitely not something we have to fuss about with you. Patient: Alright. Doctor: Okay. Just so you know cost wise, you know, no one ponies up money to just do this because, you know, you’re used to having the high ticket items for Zytiga and Xtandi but this is about fifteen thousand a dose so insurance has to clear it because that’s just the drug cost not everything else. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, in that sense you might see a bigger invoice, you know, at the end of it but most insurance companies cover it in whole Patient: Okay. Doctor: because weirdly enough it’s IV so it’s not a pill like what you’ve been on with all of your prior treatments. Patient: Right. Okay. Doctor: Anything else we’re missing? The other thing that’s hard about Xofigo though is that sometimes it doesn’t make the PSA go down. In fact, two-thirds of the people the PSA rises up and you’re like is this stuff in me, hello, are these guys pocketing it or what’s going on and it’s just something that happens bone wise that sometimes you just see almost the worsening of the PSA and yours is already going up so I bring that up so it won’t be like oh, my god, she’s ah, doesn’t she not know it’s higher. Patient: The conference we went to I learned about that. Doctor: Yes, you did.

Family Member: Alright. Doctor: Then, three days later, I get it back. He gets it in our infusion area and then that’s one treatment. And you do that a total of three times with a week in between. So within six weeks, you are finished with the therapy. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: The PSA normally doesn’t change because we don’t expect it to kill the cells right away. Family Member: Right. Doctor: But what the heck? Your PSA is going down anyways. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: But we know from looking at your scans, you have other areas that are starting to break through, we should try to do something. This is one option. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: I think a good one. It doesn’t mean that we won’t move onto, you know, pills – Family Member: Right. Doctor: - or other trials, or chemo, but this is a first step.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Student: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Student

What is the highest grade or level of s.Some college: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Some college

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay Doctor: If the shot doesn’t work out then we just have to stay very calm and either try a different shot which is a real pain in the neck shot because it’s an everyday shot for like three to four days that you would have to give yourself. Which if you can’t you would have to come here and we would give it to you, but that’s a cousin drug. Patient: Another chemo type. Doctor: No to get the white cells to remain up. Patient: Oh...Oh I see what you’re saying. Doctor: Yeah remember this is a shot… Family Member: So they don’t die… Doctor: Correct. Patient: I see oh yeah, yeah, yeah we’re still on that. Doctor: This is a shot that’s - why that shot is important is just because it’s just a one time and then it’s good. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But the alternative cheaper version of that is a daily shot to keep your cells up. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Oh, okay. Doctor: In case. Now, it wasn’t like you went all the way down zero and stayed there. So you were always around a one to two. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: You know? You’re in the fours a couple of times now, so. Patient: Um hum. Could it be because I’ll be in the sun a lot? Doctor: No. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Not that. You’re doing everything right. You are. Doctor: Everything from the music to showing up when you’re supposed to. You’re doing all the right things. Patient: Hum. Doctor: You really are. It’s just that the cancer doesn’t care. Patient: I get it.

Patient: Yeah. Um hum. Yeah. Doctor: Wait a minute. Patient: I want you to explain this to me now. Let me see my test results. Doctor: Uh, as in your-? Family Member: His PSA level, I guess. Doctor: PSA is at three point nine, today. Patient: Um hum. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: Yeah. Better than four point two. Right. But you know your scans still show two new spots in your head. Not brain. Skull. Family Member: Right. Uh huh. Doctor: So I feel like something’s definitely about to happen. You know? Break, breakthrough. Family Member: Yeah.
